title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: mixtime provides flexible time classes time series analysis forecasting mixed temporal granularities. designed handling temporal data different frequencies, making ideal : Changing observation frequencies (e.g., historical quarterly records now reported monthly) Analysis involving data different temporal resolutions (e.g., quarterly tourism monthly turnover) Forecasting temporal reconciliation across multiple time scales

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: üìà Linear Time - Create linear time vectors linear_time() helpers: * yearquarter(), yearmonth(), yearweek(), yearmonthday() üîÑ Cyclical Time - Create cyclical time vectors cyclical_time() helpers: * month_of_year(), day_of_year(), day_of_month(), day_of_week(), week_of_year() üï∞Ô∏è Time types * Discrete continuous time models * Timezone support chronons * Custom granule sizes (e.g.¬†week(2L) fortnights) * Mixed granularity vectors different temporal resolution time (series) üìÖ Calendar Systems - Support several calendars: * cal_gregorian - Gregorian dates (e.g.¬†2026-02-17) * cal_isoweek - ISO week dates (e.g.¬†2026-W8-Tue) * calendars coming, including custom censored calendars üßÆ Temporal Operations * Rounding: floor_time(), round_time(), ceiling_time() * Sequencing: seq() linear cyclical time points

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: development version can installed GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("mitchelloharawild/mixtime")

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: mixtime package designed around time units calendars. time units used create manipulate time vectors.
code: library(mixtime) demo_time <- as.POSIXct("2026-02-22 18:30:42", tz = "UTC") demo_date <- as.Date("2026-02-22")

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: Calendars cal_* prefix, contain set time units can accessed <cal>$<unit>.
code: # The Gregorian calendar cal_gregorian #> <cal_gregorian> #> Time units: #>   - year #>   - quarter #>   - month #>   - day #>   - hour #>   - minute #>   - second #>   - millisecond  # A 1-month time unit cal_gregorian$month(1L) # (1L is integer 1) #> <mixtime::tu_month> int 1 #>  @ tz: chr "UTC"  # A 2-week time unit (fortnights) cal_isoweek$week(2L) #> <mixtime::tu_week> int 2 #>  @ tz: chr "UTC"

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: linear time vector uses time units define resolution time points, known chronon (smallest unit time). input time different resolution chronon, automatically converted. Discrete time models (integer-based values) used default, however continuous time models (double-based values) can used discrete = FALSE allow fractional chronons. Linear time helper functions available quickly create common time points. mixtime package allows time different granulities combined single vector.
code: linear_time(demo_date, chronon = cal_gregorian$month(1L)) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 24313 # February 22nd is 75% through the month (in non-leap years) linear_time(demo_date, chronon = cal_gregorian$month(1L), discrete = FALSE) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 24313-75.0% # Create time vectors at different granularities yearquarter(demo_date) + 0:7 #> <mixtime[8]> #> [1] 2026-Q1 2026-Q2 2026-Q3 2026-Q4 2027-Q1 2027-Q2 2027-Q3 2027-Q4 yearmonth(demo_date) + 0:11 #> <mixtime[12]> #>  [1] 2026-Feb 2026-Mar 2026-Apr 2026-May 2026-Jun 2026-Jul 2026-Aug 2026-Sep #>  [9] 2026-Oct 2026-Nov 2026-Dec 2027-Jan yearweek(demo_date) + 0:10 #> <mixtime[11]> #>  [1] 2026-W8  2026-W9  2026-W10 2026-W11 2026-W12 2026-W13 2026-W14 2026-W15 #>  [9] 2026-W16 2026-W17 2026-W18 yearmonthday(demo_date) + 0:6 #> <mixtime[7]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-22 2026-Feb-23 2026-Feb-24 2026-Feb-25 2026-Feb-26 2026-Feb-27 #> [7] 2026-Feb-28 c(   year(demo_date), yearquarter(demo_date),    yearmonth(demo_date), yearweek(demo_date) ) #> <mixtime[4]> #> [1] 2026     2026-Q1  2026-Feb 2026-W8

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: cyclical time vector defined two calendar time units: chronon (smaller unit time) cycle (larger unit chronon loops ). several cyclical time helper functions convenience.
code: # The `calendar` argument provides a masking scope to `chronon` and `cycle` cyclical_time(demo_date, chronon = day(1L), cycle = week(1L), calendar = cal_isoweek) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Sun # Extract cyclical components month_of_year(demo_date) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Feb week_of_year(demo_date) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] W8 day_of_week(demo_date) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Sun  # Continuous cyclical time shows progress through chronons day_of_week(demo_time, discrete = FALSE) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Sun-77.1%

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: linear cyclical time vectors support timezones via tz argument.
code: demo_time #> [1] "2026-02-22 18:30:42 UTC" # Same day (Sunday) in LA yearmonthday(demo_time, tz = "America/Los_Angeles") #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-22-PST yearmonthday(demo_time, tz = "America/Los_Angeles", discrete = FALSE) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-22-10.5%-PST day_of_week(demo_time, tz = "America/Los_Angeles") #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Sun  # Next day (Monday) in Melbourne (23% through the 23rd) yearmonthday(demo_time, tz = "Australia/Melbourne") #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-23-AEDT yearmonthday(demo_time, tz = "Australia/Melbourne", discrete = FALSE) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-23-68.8%-AEDT day_of_week(demo_time, tz = "Australia/Melbourne") #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Mon

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: Linear time points can adjusted floor, ceiling, rounded specified time unit.
code: # Round dates to different granularities floor_time(demo_date, cal_gregorian$month(1L)) #> [1] "2026-02-01" round_time(demo_date, cal_isoweek$week(1L)) #> [1] "2026-02-23" ceiling_time(demo_date, cal_gregorian$month(1L)) #> [1] "2026-03-01"

title: Mixed Temporal Vectors and Operations
text: seq() function creates sequences time points iterating given time unit.
code: # Integer increments (advances by chronon's natural unit) seq(yearmonth(demo_date), by = 1L, length.out = 10) #> <mixtime[10]> #>  [1] 2026-Feb 2026-Mar 2026-Apr 2026-May 2026-Jun 2026-Jul 2026-Aug 2026-Sep #>  [9] 2026-Oct 2026-Nov  # Calendar time units allow sequencing by other units seq(yearmonthday(demo_date), by = cal_gregorian$month(1L), length.out = 8) #> <mixtime[8]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-22 2026-Mar-22 2026-Apr-22 2026-May-22 2026-Jun-22 2026-Jul-22 #> [7] 2026-Aug-22 2026-Sep-22

text: time unit object Gregorian calendar system.

title: Gregorian time unit classes ‚Äî calendar_gregorian
text: following time units available Gregorian calendar (cal_gregorian$). year(): Year unit quarter(): Quarter (3-month period) unit month(): Month unit day(): Day unit hour(): Hour unit minute(): Minute unit second(): Second unit millisecond(): Millisecond unit units form hierarchy conversions adjacent units follow Gregorian calendar rules. units fixed relationship (e.g., months days), conversion requires time context.

title: Gregorian time unit classes ‚Äî calendar_gregorian
code: # Create a custom time representation using Gregorian units linear_time(   Sys.time(),   chronon = hour(1L) ) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-Feb-24-h2

title: ISO 8601 time unit classes ‚Äî calendar_isoweek
text: following time units available ISO week date calendar: year(): ISO year unit (years start week containing first Thursday) week(): Week unit (7-day periods) day(): Day unit hour(): Hour unit minute(): Minute unit second(): Second unit millisecond(): Millisecond unit ISO 8601 weeks always start Monday first week year week containing first Thursday year. means days early January may belong last week previous ISO year, days late December may belong first week next ISO year.

text: Time unit constructors civil time system boundary day midnight 24 hour clock. calendar intended built calendars (e.g. [cal_time_civil_midnight] [cal_isoweek]) add common time components.  units can used linear_time() create custom time representations.

title: Cyclical time points ‚Äî cyclical_time

title: Cyclical time points ‚Äî cyclical_time

title: Cyclical time points ‚Äî cyclical_time
text: data Input data convert cyclical time. Can : Numeric values (interpreted chronons, 1-indexed) Character strings (parsed dates/times) Date POSIXct objects time objects chronon time unit expression representing chronon (smallest indivisible time unit), evaluated context calendar. Use unquoted expressions like day(1L) month(1L). Chronons specific calendar can also used (e.g. cal_isoweek$day(1L)). cycle time unit expression representing cycle (larger time unit defines period), evaluated context calendar. Use unquoted expressions like week(1L) year(1L). tz Time zone time representation. Defaults time zone input data (tz_name(data)). Time zones need valid identifiers IANA time zone database (tzdb::tzdb_names()) discrete Logical. TRUE (default), returns integer positions within cycle (discrete time model). FALSE, returns fractional positions allowing representation partial time units (continuous time model). calendar Calendar system used evaluate chronon cycle. Defaults time_calendar(data) existing time objects. Common options include cal_gregorian cal_isoweek.

title: Cyclical time points ‚Äî cyclical_time
code: # Day of week (1-7, Monday = 1) cyclical_time(   Sys.Date(),   chronon = day(1L),   cycle = week(1L),   calendar = cal_isoweek ) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Tue  # Month of year (1-12) cyclical_time(   Sys.Date(),   chronon = month(1L),   cycle = year(1L) ) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] Feb  # Discrete vs continuous time # yearweek(x) is linear_time(x, chronon = day(1L), cycle = week(1L), calendar = cal_isoweek) yearweek(Sys.time(), discrete = TRUE) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-W9 yearweek(Sys.time(), discrete = FALSE) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 2026-W9-15.6%  # Day of month with Gregorian calendar cyclical_time(   Sys.Date(),   chronon = day(1L),   cycle = month(1L),   calendar = cal_gregorian ) #> <mixtime[1]> #> [1] 24

title: Base S7 class for creating new time units ‚Äî mt_unit
text: Time units building blocks calendars mixtime. unit represents specific temporal component (e.g., day, month, year) can combined using new_calendar() create calendar system. creating custom calendars, define time unit classes inherit either mt_unit (standard units) mt_tz_unit (timezone-aware units), pass named arguments new_calendar(). calendar use names create constructor functions accessible via $ notation (e.g., calendar$day(1L)).

title: Base S7 class for creating new time units ‚Äî mt_unit
text: Time units enable calendar arithmetic two key generic methods implemented custom time units: chronon_cardinality(, , ) - Returns number units fit within one unit. can fixed value (e.g., 7 days per week) variable based (e.g., 28-31 days per month). chronon_divmod(x, , ) - Converts time unit x units units , returning list chronon (quotient) remainder. enables conversions units variable cardinality (e.g., date 2020-03-23 month 2020-03). conversions based chronons since epoch (1970-01-01), UTC time zone. methods work together enable mixtime perform calendar-aware arithmetic, understanding months variable lengths handling timezone-aware conversions.

title: Round, floor and ceiling transformations for time objects ‚Äî round_time
text: x date/time object rounded. Accepted types include Date, POSIXct, POSIXlt objects inherit POSIXt. returned object class input. unit time unit (object coercible time unit, e.g. "day"). ... Additional arguments passed specific implementations.

title: Round, floor and ceiling transformations for time objects ‚Äî round_time
code: # Round POSIXct to the nearest minute (preserving tz) t <- as.POSIXct("2020-01-01 12:34:56", tz = "UTC") round_time(t, unit = cal_gregorian$minute(1L)) #> [1] "2020-01-01 12:35:00 UTC"  # Floor to the nearest hour floor_time(t, unit = cal_gregorian$hour(1L)) #> [1] "2020-01-01 12:00:00 UTC"  # Ceiling a Date (treated as midnight-of-day rounding) d <- as.Date("2020-01-01") ceiling_time(d, unit = cal_gregorian$month(1L)) #> [1] "2020-02-01"

title: Generate sequences of mixtime values ‚Äî seq.mixtime
code: # S3 method for class 'mixtime' seq(...)  # S3 method for class 'mt_linear' seq(   from,   to,   by,   length.out = NULL,   along.with = NULL,   on_invalid = c("nearest", "overflow"),   ... )  # S3 method for class 'mt_cyclical' seq(from, to, by, length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, ...)

title: Generate sequences of mixtime values ‚Äî seq.mixtime
text: ... Additional arguments passed underlying sequence method. Starting value sequence. End value sequence (provided). Increment sequence. Can : integer number time units character string specifying interval (e.g., "1 day", "2 weeks", "1 month", "1 year") time unit object created time unit functions (e.g., cal_gregorian$year(1L), cal_gregorian$month(1L), cal_gregorian$day(1L)) length.Desired length sequence (alternative ). along.Take length argument (alternative length.). on_invalid handle time points overflow cycle using argument different time units sequence type. Options : "nearest" (default): Adjust overflowing time points nearest valid time point within cycle "overflow": Allow time points overflow next cycle relevant starting time point offset exist cycles. example, starting day 31 = "1 month" overflow months fewer 31 days (e.g., February). "nearest", adjusted last day month (e.g., Feb 28/29). "overflow", extra days carry next month. explicitly specified overflow occurs, warning issued default "nearest" behavior applied.

title: Generate sequences of mixtime values ‚Äî seq.mixtime
text: mixtime vector containing sequence.

title: Generate sequences of mixtime values ‚Äî seq.mixtime
text: linear time types (Date, POSIXct, yearmonth, etc.), sequences progress forward backward time. cyclical time types (month_of_year, day_of_week, etc.), sequences wrap around cyclically.

title: Generate sequences of mixtime values ‚Äî seq.mixtime
code: # Linear time sequences with integer by seq(yearmonth("2020-01-01"), yearmonth("2020-12-01")) #> <mixtime[12]> #>  [1] 2020-Jan 2020-Feb 2020-Mar 2020-Apr 2020-May 2020-Jun 2020-Jul 2020-Aug #>  [9] 2020-Sep 2020-Oct 2020-Nov 2020-Dec seq(yearquarter("2020-01-01"), length.out = 5, by = 3) #> <mixtime[5]> #> [1] 2020-Q1 2020-Q4 2021-Q3 2022-Q2 2023-Q1  # Linear time sequences with string intervals seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-01"), yearmonthday("2020-12-31"), by = "1 month") #> <mixtime[12]> #>  [1] 2020-Jan-1 2020-Feb-1 2020-Mar-1 2020-Apr-1 2020-May-1 2020-Jun-1 #>  [7] 2020-Jul-1 2020-Aug-1 2020-Sep-1 2020-Oct-1 2020-Nov-1 2020-Dec-1 seq(yearmonth("2020-01-01"), yearmonth("2025-01-01"), by = "1 year") #> <mixtime[6]> #> [1] 2020-Jan 2021-Jan 2022-Jan 2023-Jan 2024-Jan 2025-Jan seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-01"), length.out = 10, by = "2 weeks") #> <mixtime[10]> #>  [1] 2020-Jan-1  2020-Jan-15 2020-Jan-29 2020-Feb-12 2020-Feb-26 2020-Mar-11 #>  [7] 2020-Mar-25 2020-Apr-8  2020-Apr-22 2020-May-6   # Linear time sequences with time units seq(yearmonth("2020-01-01"), yearmonth("2020-12-01"), by = cal_gregorian$month(2L)) #> <mixtime[6]> #> [1] 2020-Jan 2020-Mar 2020-May 2020-Jul 2020-Sep 2020-Nov seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-01"), length.out = 5, by = cal_gregorian$year(1L)) #> <mixtime[5]> #> [1] 2020-Jan-1 2021-Jan-1 2022-Jan-1 2023-Jan-1 2024-Jan-1 seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-01"), yearmonthday("2020-01-31"), by = cal_gregorian$day(7L)) #> <mixtime[5]> #> [1] 2020-Jan-1  2020-Jan-8  2020-Jan-15 2020-Jan-22 2020-Jan-29  # Handling invalid dates with on_invalid seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-31"), length.out = 3, by = "1 month")  # warns, uses nearest #> Warning: The cycle offset (31 days) has produced time points that overflow the month #> cycle. #> ! Using the nearest valid time points in the cycle, `on_invalid = "nearest"` #>   (the default). #> ‚Ñπ Specify `on_invalid` explicitly to suppress this warning. #> <mixtime[3]> #> [1] 2020-Jan-31 2020-Feb-29 2020-Mar-31 seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-31"), length.out = 3, by = "1 month", on_invalid = "nearest") #> <mixtime[3]> #> [1] 2020-Jan-31 2020-Feb-29 2020-Mar-31 seq(yearmonthday("2020-01-31"), length.out = 3, by = "1 month", on_invalid = "overflow") #> <mixtime[3]> #> [1] 2020-Jan-31 2020-Mar-2  2020-Mar-31  # Cyclical time sequences seq(month_of_year(0L), month_of_year(11L)) #> <mixtime[12]> #>  [1] Dec Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Oct Nov seq(month_of_year(5L), month_of_year(3L), by = cal_gregorian$month(2L)) #> <mixtime[6]> #> [1] May Jul Sep Nov Jan Mar seq(day_of_week(0L), day_of_week(6L), by = 1) #> <mixtime[7]> #> [1] Wed Thu Fri Sat Sun Mon Tue
